Posts.Content: May 5, 2008 08:35AM burns_la wrote: Anne: so sorry! I've had the post mast syndrome since lymph node dissection in 2004. Tried a lot of things, with little result. I found that the pain is both random and activity based. Limiting use and a glass of red wine with an endocet seem to do more than anything. I am also on Cymbalta for the neuropathy altho' I won't discount the help with the depression over this. I also find that keeping up with my LE self massage helps since the LE increases the pain also. My PCP has been fabulous in helping experiment with different pain meds and different antidepressants to find the combo that works best for me. I applied for (and fought for) SSDI and got it. You can PM me if you have any other questions, if you wish, or just ask here and I'll help if I can. God bless.

Posts.Title: Ovaries removed tommorrow -Scared Stefanie MargaretB

Posts.Content: Nov 6, 2008 12:19PM burns_la wrote: Mom2two: I call mine post-lymph node dissection syndrome. I had my surgeries in 2004 and am still fighting the pain. I don't want to pressure or worry you. There are many more of us who find ways to alleviate the pain. Many anti-depressants are effective on phantom nerve pain as well as different therapies and even accupuncture. The main thing I found is that you should get referred to a pain clinic if you have one in your area and keep the faith. The thing I found is - as you've discovered - it is much easier to avoid the pain than to alleviate it. I do my daily activities in short bursts with a lot of resting in between. You can PM me if you have any questions. Hugs and prayers.

Posts.Content: Jul 7, 2008 12:19PM burns_la wrote: My first dx was 12/31/03 (Happy New Year!) and I still have those moments of toal despair over "what happened to me!" No matter how many times I tell myself I am 54 and would not be the same as my 21 year old self, it doesn't help. I guess because simple aging is inevitable, so the wrinkles and weight gain aren't as depressing. But, to look in the mirror before a shower (guess this is fairly common!!!!!) is still a time for tears over my loss. My scars, thinning hair, mis-shapen and mis-matched boobs, piled ON TOP of the normal aging issues, and I want to double up on the anti-depressants! And for some reason (as already discussed) the port scar is the worst because it is the most-often visible. A few days ago we were out to dinner with some old friends and new friends, and a new friend (a man) asked my husband how I was doing with my cancer because he recognized the port scar for what it was. Just about the time you think you "clean up pretty good", BAM you get hit again with the facts.

Posts.Content: Dec 11, 2008 10:54AM burns_la wrote: Hi all. I had a RMast/Immed Tram for DCIS, but the mast path came back invasive, so had to have a subsequent lymph node dissection on the R side to check for spread. Too late for the SNB! Well, I awoke during the surgery with pain and have had it ever since (2004). Have tried the different modes of treatment, thanks to a wonderful PC. Combination of anti-depressant and pain meds works fairly well for me. However, the best way to avoid the pain is to avoid using my right arm or hand (and I'm right handed!). I found prevention is much better than dealing with the pain after it starts! Usually, this is called post-mastectomy pain syndrome or post-lymph node dissection pain syndrome, and it is caused by damage to the intercostobrachial (sp?) nerve during surgery. Feels kind of like wearing a hot barbed-wire bra to begin with, then the pain spreads all down my right arm, through my right axilla, and across my right foob. Do I get to be the first to say "I feel your pain!!!!!"
Posts.Title: Post surgery NERVE PAIN seacat mjm1

Posts.Content: Nov 17, 2008 10:43AM burns_la wrote: I was diagnosed 12/31/03 and am still sad. Part of my treatment (lymph node removal) left me with permanent nerve damage for which I take daily pain meds and daily anti-depressants due to their helping with nerve pain. WITH all that, I am still sad and occasionally cry. It is definitely one step at a time, but now I don't have any steps left to take. No more active treatment, so I should be good! NOT! I think it is like post-traumatic stress sydrome. Do people get over that? How do they do it?

Posts.Content: Nov 14, 2008 10:39AM burns_la wrote: My understanding is that the benefits are awarded not based on diagnosis but activities of daily living. You are automatic on Stage IV, that doesn't mean you can't get it if you aren't Stage IV. They look at what your symptoms are and what you can or cannot do on a daily basis. I got it based on that and not at all on staging. I agree - apply and take it from there...

Posts.Content: Nov 8, 2008 10:55AM burns_la wrote: I didn't want a recliner at ALL because I am so short the only way I can get out of one is to use my arms. I found that if I was laying on my back in bed and wanted to get up, I just folded my arms across my chest (gently!) and rolled over on my stomach. While rolling, I pulled my legs up so that I could just roll and get my feet on the floor. I could then use my legs and stomach to stand up. BOY, is that hard to describe! Hope you get the idea - it worked for me as I didn't have to use my arms...

Posts.Content: Apr 13, 2007 02:13PM burns_la wrote: I think waxing would be safer than shaving when dealing with LE. I was just planning to make a appt. to wax mine. My thought is that there is no chance of a cut. Also, since my lymph node removal on my TRAM side, my "armpit" is shaped very differently, with a big "hollow" - this makes it even harder to shave. Also, after so many waxings, the hair will be less noticable and fewer and finer to boot...
Posts.Title: armpit waxing earlybird sherry7

Posts.Content: Jan 5, 2009 11:53AM burns_la wrote: Hi, TJW. I have truncal/right side LE and also have neuropathy. They are not inclusive nor caused by each other as far as I know. The neuropathy I have is from a damaged/cut nerve obtained during lymph node dissection. I can tell you the pain I feel from each is very different. The LE pain is more like a heaviness and achiness.  The nerve pain is sharp and feels like I am wearing a barbed-wire bra. After overuse, my nerve pain is definitely worse, while the LE pain seems much more random. At this point, I use "over-the-counter" bras which are really shape wear. I get the camisole type garments that are snug - this seems to work very well for me and when the LE flares up, I even wear them to bed. Please work with the LE clinic, they helped me quite a lot. Hugs and prayers from a true sister. Soon you will get more advice, I'm sure.

Posts.Content: May 27, 2008 03:48PM burns_la wrote: Of all the pains I had during all of my surgeries and treatments, the port pain was different and the most memorable. It took "forever" to feel better. I think part of it is that it's right at the skin and is affected by movement of either arm. Also, sleeping was very hard! I found that sleeping on my stomach was easiest. Sounds wrong, like it would hurt the most, but I think it isolated the movement of arms or neck more. I understand your concern and feel your pain (sorry :). It does get getter with time. Try sleeping on your stomach if you can. ((hugs))
